qas.question: Who witnessed first-hand and wrote about the Great Fire of 1666?
What area has historically been the literary hub of London?
A more current, 20th century center for London's literary set is located where?
Which author's novels painted a dismal portrait of Victorian London?
What female writer is one of the leading literary minds of the 20th century?

context: London has been the setting for many works of literature. The literary centres of London have traditionally been hilly <a1_0>Hampstead<a1_0/> and (since the early 20th century) <a2_0>Bloomsbury<a2_0/>. Writers closely associated with the city are the diarist <a0_0>Samuel Pepys<a0_0/>, noted for his eyewitness account of the Great Fire, <a3_0>Charles Dickens<a3_0/>, whose representation of a foggy, snowy, grimy London of street sweepers and pickpockets has been a major influence on people's vision of early Victorian London, and <a4_0>Virginia Woolf<a4_0/>, regarded as one of the foremost modernist literary figures of the 20th century.
